isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - DRIVETRAIN FAILURE ANALYSIS - CLUTCH COMPONENTS - DRIVEN DISCS

step2.para: Leakage at transmission bearing cap or engine rear main seal.
Failure to remove rust preventative from the flywheel.
The transmission input shaft was greased.

note.para: Greasing the transmission input shaft is NOT recommended. This practice can lead to clutch release problems.

step1.para: Warped driven discs result when the transmission is hung unsupported during installation.

Burnt driven discs are a result of excessive heat due to slippage. Ceramic facing material will flow and eventually separate from the disc. Organic material will separate from the disc due to bonding agent failure. Burnt discs can result from:

step2.para: Partial unloading of a clutch due to a binding linkage system.

step1.para: Driven disc to release retainer interference is the result of incorrect adjustment. The linkage was adjusted to compensate for wear rather than the internal adjusting ring. This can cause cracked hubs in the rear disc and a cracked pressure plate from the heat generated ( Figure 26).

Rigid disc splines excessively worn or disc cracked. The cause of worn splines is usually due to torsional vibration or misapplication ( Figure 27). A cracked disc hub ( Figure 28) can be caused by the following:

step2.para: Misalignment between the transmission clutch housing and the engine housing.
Misapplication - a rigid disc should not have been used.
The transmission was hung in the disc unsupported during installation.

step1.para: Cracked damper cover ( Figure 29) can result from:

step2.para: Forcing the transmission input shaft into the driven disc hub during installation.
Allowing the transmission to hang unsupported in the driven disc hub during installation.
Misalignment between the engine housing and the transmission clutch housing.

step1.para: Broken or missing damper springs may result from severe shock loads or excessive torsional vibration from the engine over the design limit of the damper ( Figure 30).

figure.caption: Figure 30. Broken and Missing Damper Springs

step1.para: Driven disc damper hub cracked due to severe shock load or powertrain torsional vibration ( Figure 31).

figure.caption: Figure 31. Cracked Driven Disc Damper Hub

step1.para: Cracked or broken driven disc due to a severe shock load ( Figure 32).

figure.caption: Figure 32. Cracked or Broken Driven Disc

step1.para: Facings separate from the driven disc and the pressure plate, center plate and flywheel show severe damage caused by excessive slippage ( Figure 33).

step2.para: Insufficient clutch torque capacity for the application.
